Extending Sierra with New Tools
This tutorial will demonstrate how to add new tools to Sierra by adding the well-known tool CheckStyle. To begin with, the general data flow for a given tool is as follows:
At startup, Sierra scans for available tools, and instantiates an IToolFactory for each one.
For a given scan of a set of projects, Sierra specifies the files to be scanned, as well as other parameters, in a Config object.
Sierra uses this to create an ILazyArtifactGenerator, which encapsulates the creation of the resulting scan document.
Sierra then uses both the Config and ILazyArtifactGenerator to call create() on each IToolFactory to create an IToolInstance specific to that Config
For each IToolInstance, Sierra will call run() with an ArtifactGenerator to create a scan document???
There are two approaches to doing this:
Loose integration, where we run the tool normally and convert the results into the appropriate format.
Tight integration, where we write a custom application that effectively uses the tool as a library, and feed the results directly into the ArtifactGenerator.
The difference is that the former can use existing configuration files and thus requires less development time, but usually takes more run time to convert the results. The latter requires more
Either way, we can begin by using the Sierra Tool Plugin Project wizard to create the basic structure for our new tool plugin.
